greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: a(n) = Sum_{d|n} n!/(d!*(n/d)!).
comment: a(n) = 2 for prime n. It appears that all terms belong to A100195 (Numbers n such that the denominator of BernoulliB[n] is a record). - _Alexander Adamchuk_, Sep 09 2006
a(468) has 1007 decimal digits. - _Michael De Vlieger_, Sep 12 2018
Number of matrices whose entries are 1,...,n, up to row and column permutations. For example, inequivalent representatives of the a(4) = 8 matrices are:
link: Michael De Vlieger, Table of n, a(n) for n = 1..467
Jimmy Devillet, Gergely Kiss, Characterizations of biselective operations, arXiv:1806.02073 [math.RA], 2018.
mathematica: f[n_] := Block[{d = Divisors@n}, Plus @@ (n!/(d! (n/d)!))]; Array[f, 25] (* _Robert G. Wilson v_, Sep 11 2006 *)
program: (PARI) a(n) = sumdiv(n, d, n!/(d!*(n/d)!)); \\ _Michel Marcus_, Sep 13 2018
